docs.lead_paragraph: One year ago this week, President Obama signed the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act into law. The anniversary will be marked by a series of events from proponents and opponents of the law who are still waging a pitched battle over provisions of the health care legislation.
docs.abstract: Many public events this week will be devoted to lauding and denouncing the one-year-old health care law.
docs.snippet: Many public events this week will be devoted to lauding and denouncing the one-year-old health care law.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline.main: Monday Reading: Insurance for People with Pre-Existing Conditions

docs.abstract: New insurance plans for people with pre-existing conditions, Buffett slaps a buy on Japan and other consumer news from The Times.
docs.snippet: New insurance plans for people with pre-existing conditions, Buffett slaps a buy on Japan and other consumer news from The Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: The suit, brought on behalf of people who were at Memorial Hospital during Hurricane Katrina, will weigh whether the hospital’s owner should be held accountable for deaths related to the disaster.

docs.lead_paragraph: Health officials are taking a look at neonatal intensive care units, or NICU’s, and questioning whether they are being used in cases where they aren’t necessary.

docs.lead_paragraph: Packers fans and shareholders had little time to celebrate their Super Bowl victory before the N.F.L. lockout.

headline.seo: N.F.L. Lockout Leaves Green Bay With a Title, but No Team
headline.main: Green Bay Is Left a Town With a Title but No Team
headline.print_headline: Green Bay Is Left a Town With a Title, but No Team

docs.abstract: Potential for lost games over NFL lockout means more to Green Bay, Wis, than most other NFL cities; economy and psyche of league's smallest market is inextricably tied to Green Bay Packers football.
docs.snippet: Packers fans and shareholders had little time to celebrate their Super Bowl victory before the N.F.L. lockout.

docs.lead_paragraph: A bus crash in the Bronx a week ago opened a window not only on the Chinese bus business, but also on an American immigrant tradition: the ethnic occupational niche.
